title: Reaction Rate Investigation
instructions: Investigate how temperature affects the decomposition rate of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) using MnO₂ as a catalyst. Measure the volume of O₂ gas produced per minute at different temperatures.
steps: Prepare 50 mL of 3% H₂O₂ solution. Set up a gas collection apparatus (inverted measuring cylinder over water).
At 10°C (ice bath): add 0.5 g MnO₂ to H₂O₂. Record volume of O₂ collected every 30 seconds for 3 minutes.
Repeat at 20°C, 30°C, 40°C, and 50°C. Keep MnO₂ mass constant.
Plot volume of O₂ vs time for each temperature. Calculate initial rate (steepest gradient).
Plot ln(rate) vs 1/T to determine activation energy using the Arrhenius equation.
Confirm MnO₂ is unchanged at the end (weigh it) — verify it is a catalyst.
expected_outcome: Rate approximately doubles for every 10°C rise. The ln(rate) vs 1/T graph is linear with slope −Eₐ/R. MnO₂ mass is unchanged, confirming catalytic behaviour.
self_check_rubric: Did rate approximately double with each 10°C increase in temperature?
Is your Arrhenius plot (ln k vs 1/T) linear?
Is the estimated activation energy in the range 40–80 kJ/mol?
Did you verify that MnO₂ mass was unchanged (confirming catalysis)?
Did you control all variables except temperature throughout the experiment?
